710\adjustright \b\fs32 {General Executive Summary for W.R. Grace & Co. \endash  Conn., Darex Specialty Polymers, Owensboro, Kentucky Facility}{\fs24 

\par }\pard\plain \widctlpar\adjustright \fs20\cgrid {\fs24\cgrid0 

\par }\pard \qj\fi-360\li360\sa120\widctlpar\adjustright {\b\fs28\cgrid0 1.\tab Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

\par }\pard \qj\widctlpar\adjustright {\fs24\cgrid0 

We at W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, ins

tallation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.

\par 

\par 

\par }\pard \qj\fi-360\li360\sa120\widctlpar\adjustright {\b\fs28\cgrid0 2.\tab The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

\par }\pard \qj\widctlpar\adjustright {\fs24\cgrid0 

Our facility's primary activities encompass The primary activity at the Owensboro facility is the production of various latex polymers, NAICS code 325211 (formerly Standard Industrial Classification ("SIC") Code 2821).  We have 

3 regulated substances present at our facility.  These substances include Acrylonitrile  [2-Propenenitrile], Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester] and Vinylidene chloride [Ethene, 1,1-dichloro-].  The regulated substances at our facility are 

involved in several uses.  Acrylonitrile, Vinyl Acetate and Vinylidene Chloride are used for manufacturing liquid latex emulsion polymers.

\par 

\par The total quantities handled/stored for each regulated substance, used for determination of Offsite Consequence Analy

sis (OCA), are - Vinyl acetate monomer [Acetic acid ethenyl ester] is 33,603 lb., Vinylidene chloride [Ethene, 1,1-dichloro-] is 407,100

lb., and Acrylonitrile  [2-Propenenitrile] is 139,939 lb.  A summary description of each of the production processes i

s set forth below. 

\par 

\par \tab 1.\tab Polyvinylidene Chloride (DARAN)

\par 

\par a.\tab Process Description: Emulsion polymerizations of 1,1-Dichloroethylene with other monomers such as acrylonitrile and various acrylates.   Polyvinylidene Chloride emulsions are high barrier, flexibl

e, crystalline polymers designed for coating paper, paperboard, plastic films and metal.  Polyvinylidene Chloride is made in glass-lined or stainless steel reactors by semi-batchwise emulsion polymerization.

\par 

\par b.\tab Primary Equipment:  Reactor trains 200 (A), 210 (B), 220 (C) and 230 (154).

\par 

\par \tab 2.\tab Acrylic Polymers (DAXAD)

\par 

\par a.\tab Process Description:  A poly-methacrylate dispersing agent used in latex paints, ceramics and electronics.  Acrylic polymers are made in a stainless steel reactor by batchwise saponification

 and subsequent polymerization of methyl methacrylate or methacrylic acid.

\par 

\par b.\tab Primary Equipment:  Reactor train 360.

\par 

\par                 3.\tab Polyvinyl Acetate (PVA)

\par 

\par a.\tab Process Description:  PVA consists of a wide variety of polyvinyl acetate emulsion polymers used in adhesives, caulk, concrete and paint.  PVA is made in a stainless steel reactor by batchwise and semi-batchwise emulsion polymerization.

\par 

\par b.\tab Primary Equipment:  Reactor train 157.

\par 

\par \tab 4.\tab Developmental Process (R-1117)

\par 

\par a.\tab Process Description:  R-1117 is a cationic acrylic polymer emulsion. This acrylic polymer emulsion is used in the production of various types of container labels.  R-1117 is made in the 1000 gallon experimental glass-lined  reactor. 

\par 

\par b.\tab Primary Equipment:  Reactor train 650.

\par 

\par 

\par }\pard \qj\fi-360\li360\sa120\widctlpar\adjustright {\b\fs28\cgrid0 3.\tab 

The Worst Case Release Scenario(s) and the

Alternative Release Scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario

\par }\pard \qj\widctlpar\adjustright {\fs24\cgrid0 In compliance with EPA's revised rule governin

g the changes to the Chemical Accident Prevention Rule (Risk Management Program) in 2004, the Worst Case and Alternative Case Release Scenarios have been omitted from the Executive Summary.

\par 

\par 

\par }\pard \qj\fi-360\li360\sa120\widctlpar\adjustright {\b\fs28\cgrid0 4.\tab The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

\par }\pard \qj\widctlpar\adjustright {\fs24\cgrid0 

Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  A number of processes at our facility are subject to the OSHA PSM standar

d under 29 CFR 1910.119.  Our facility is subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements and we also have a Clean Air Act, Title V air operating permit.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that i

s in place at our stationary source.

\par 

\par Process Safety Information

\par W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated 

with all processes.  Some examples of the process safety information include Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) on all raw materials and products, Equipment Specification Sheets, and Process Instrumentation and Design drawings (P&ID).

\par 

\par Process Hazard Analysis

\par Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is Checklist and HAZOP.  The studies are undertaken by a team 

of qualified personnel with exper

tise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of not greater than five (5) years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA/up

date was performed on 07/11/2002.

\par 

\par Operating Procedures

\par For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address vario

us modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators

 involved in the processes.

\par 

\par Training

\par W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these proce

sses.  Refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years and more frequently as needed.

\par 

\par Mechanical Integrity

\par W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, 

relief and vent sys

tems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment 

deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

\par 

\par Management of Change

\par Written procedures are in place at W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equi

pment and procedur

es.  The most recent review/revision of maintenance procedures was performed on 07/22/2003.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly

 made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

\par 

\par Pre-startup Reviews

\par Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers.  The most recent review was performed on 06/4/2004

.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

\par 

\par Compliance Audits

\par W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on 11/20/2002.  The

se audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

\par 

\par Incident Investigation

\par W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers promptly investigates any 

incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release f

rom reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

\par 

\par Employee Participation

\par W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are st

rongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have

access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including informatio

n resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

\par 

\par Contractors

\par On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of 

the contractor is carried out.  W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the proce

dures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

\par 

\par 

\par }\pard \qj\fi-360\li360\sa120\widctlpar\adjustright {\b\fs28\cgrid0 5.\tab Five-year Accident History

\par }\pard \qj\widctlpar\adjustright {\fs24\cgrid0 W. R. Grace & Co -- CONN, Darex Specialty Polymers has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.

  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, only one accidental release has occurred during this period.

\par 

\par There has been only one accidental release of a regulated substance from our facility within the last 5 years.  This release took place on 05/

21/2003 and involved 934 lb. of Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester].  No deaths or injuries occurred offsite as a result of this accident.  Onsite, there were no deaths or injuries.  There was some onsite property damage.  

\par 

\par 

\par }\pard \qj\fi-360\li360\sa120\widctlpar\adjustright {\b\fs28\cgrid0 6.\tab Emergency Response Plan

\par }\pard \qj\widctlpar\adjustright {\fs24\cgrid0 Grace carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical

 treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response age

ncies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

\par 

\par To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In 

addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.

\par 

\par Owensboro Daviess County is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.

\par 

\par 

\par }\pard \qj\fi-360\li360\sa120\widctlpar\adjustright {\b\fs28\cgrid0 7.\tab Planned Changes to Improve Safety

\par }\pard \qj\widctlpar\adjustright {\fs24\cgrid0 Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program.  Security Vulnerability Assessment 

(SVA)  countermeasures, Industrial Hygiene (IH) on-going sampling, Risk Reduction Project to move flammable transfer lines/pumps into containment dikes, and PVdC Stainless Steel Reactor Evaluation - PVdC corrosion studies are being accomplished to underst

and risk as well as future PVdC product growth in existing equipment are some of the major steps we want to take to improve safety at our facility.  These changes are expected to be implemented by 12/31/05.

\par 

\par 

\par Name:  Eric F. Squire

\par }}
